text: Yep, I do this as a side gig. If it’s just the linkedin post (vs a full article), I’d ask at least $8/post.

elements.text: Yep, I do this as a side gig. If it’s just the linkedin post (vs a full article), I’d ask at least $8/post.

text: I actually charge more for shorter social pieces due to the limitations on length. Sometimes I'll frame it on per hour basis vs wordcount if most of the time is spent editing a concept down to fit into a tweet or post.

elements.text: I actually charge more for shorter social pieces due to the limitations on length. Sometimes I'll frame it on per hour basis vs wordcount if most of the time is spent editing a concept down to fit into a tweet or post.

text:
Hey :wave:

I've been writing <https://www.linkedin.com/posts/fiorenzadossetto_contentmarketing-activity-6720310896335306752-0bLZ|a mini-series on LinkedIn> to share the main lessons I learned as a Senior Editor, in case any other editors/marketers/content creators out there can use some of it. Today's lesson is probably the most important one of them all... so I thought I'd share it here with you and ask a follow-up question.

The lesson →  if you don’t care about your audience, you can’t expect them to care about you.

The question → do you have any examples/stories you can share about what this looks like in practice? How do YOU put the audience at the center of what you do? I am looking for inspiration and figured this is the best place to find some... Thank you! :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
What are your thoughts on Article title case? Do you see more returns on using Upper-case for each word or using sentence-case?

I'm guessing bigger brands have a Style Guide on this. Lately, I've been doing a mixture of both on my articles.

elements.text:
What are your thoughts on Article title case? Do you see more returns on using Upper-case for each word or using sentence-case?

I'm guessing bigger brands have a Style Guide on this. Lately, I've been doing a mixture of both on my articles.

text: <@URB31QKM4>, here's a Sprout article with lower-case. any specific reason?

elements.text: , here's a Sprout article with lower-case. any specific reason?

text:
So true <@U017WRJTKF1>. I’m really enjoying your series! One example that our team was really proud of was the “Always On” series we created last year. It was very audience driven:
• Started with data from an annual survey of our core audience (social media professionals) on their top challenges
• We identified social media pros who were effectively solving for one of these top challenges
• Conducted audio and video interviews to showcase a day in the life and understand how they were tackling this challenge, and what others could learn
• Created a video feature of each as well as a blog post recapping some of the more tactical ways they solve their challenge, and then broke those into dozens of shorter video clips, GIFs, templates, etc.
Here’s one example featuring Lindsay Bruce, who at the time was the marketing coordinator for @TwitterBusiness. <https://sproutsocial.com/insights/always-on-lindsay-bruce/>

attachments.title: Always On: 4 ways I understand our audience better every day, with Twitter’s Lindsay Bruce
attachments.text: As the Marketing coordinator behind @TwitterBusiness, here are four ways Lindsay Bruce gets to know her audience inside and out.
attachments.fallback: Sprout Social: Always On: 4 ways I understand our audience better every day, with Twitter’s Lindsay Bruce

elements.text: So true
. I’m really enjoying your series! One example that our team was really proud of was the “Always On” series we created last year. It was very audience driven:
Started with data from an annual survey of our core audience (social media professionals) on their top challenges
We identified social media pros who were effectively solving for one of these top challenges
Conducted audio and video interviews to showcase a day in the life and understand how they were tackling this challenge, and what others could learn

Created a video feature of each as well as a blog post recapping some of the more tactical ways they solve their challenge, and then broke those into dozens of shorter video clips, GIFs, templates, etc.
Here’s one example featuring Lindsay Bruce, who at the time was the marketing coordinator for @TwitterBusiness.

text: I've always preferred sentence case. I think I read some Nielsen research on it aaaaggggeees ago, but intuitively people read more sentences than anything else — so it makes sense to make headlines more readable?

elements.text: I've always preferred sentence case. I think I read some Nielsen research on it aaaaggggeees ago, but intuitively people read more sentences than anything else — so it makes sense to make headlines more readable?

text: Same here, <@UJ7RT1J1X>! I gravitate toward sentence case when reading articles. It seems most stuff out there is upper-case. ha.

elements.text: Same here,
! I gravitate toward sentence case when reading articles. It seems most stuff out there is upper-case. ha.

text: We do headlines in sentence case, which was a switch we made a few years ago for the reasons <@UJ7RT1J1X> mentioned. Titles (of events, guides, etc) are title cased. The rationale for headlines is that it feels more conversational and approachable for the reader. Here’s more from our style guide: <https://seeds.sproutsocial.com/writing/grammar-and-mechanics#headline-formatting>

attachments.title: Grammar and mechanics
attachments.text: Guidelines on proper use of commas, hyphens, periods, numbers, times, etc.

text:
Generally, we specify all title tags as Title Case.

Usually Title Case for headlines also, although it depends on our client and their style.

We start seeing clients using sentence case in H2, H3 subheadings for informational articles (blogs, guides, etc.) Those subheads often mirror and target Google PAAs, which are almost always sentence case.

text: :smile:

Thank <@U017WRJTKF1> for sharing this here. I joined the conversation over on LinkdeIn.
Your example is great. I certainly don’t have this nailed, but one thing I am becoming a bit fanatical about is
• recording as many calls as possible when I meet with prospects or customers. 
• I also force myself to write up my call notes immediately after the call. 
• I review the notes when thinking about priority for new content (and as the business leader, when thinking about product priorities, as well).
